output.conclusion: By completing this course, you will have a strong understanding of chemical bonding principles and their applications in various chemical systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Chemical Bonding! This course delves into the intricacies of chemical bonds, exploring advanced theories and applications relevant to modern chemistry.

chapters.description: Review of Lewis structures, resonance, and formal charge calculations. Advanced examples and exceptions to the octet rule.
Advanced applications of VSEPR theory to predict molecular shapes. Consideration of lone pair effects and distortions.
Calculating dipole moments from bond dipoles. Predicting molecular polarity based on geometry and electronegativity.
Introduction to valence bond theory and its limitations. Hybridization of atomic orbitals and sigma/pi bonding.
Detailed analysis of sp, sp2, sp3, sp3d, and sp3d2 hybridization. Predicting hybridization based on molecular geometry.
Advanced treatment of resonance structures and electron delocalization. Molecular orbital perspective on resonance.
Introduction to molecular orbital theory. Constructing MO diagrams for diatomic molecules (H2, O2, N2, etc.).
Calculating bond order from MO diagrams. Predicting magnetic properties (paramagnetism, diamagnetism).
MO diagrams for heteronuclear diatomic molecules (CO, NO, HF). Effects of electronegativity differences.
Introduction to band theory. Formation of energy bands in solids. Conductors, semiconductors, and insulators.
n-type and p-type semiconductors. Effects of doping on conductivity.
The electron sea model. Properties of metals (conductivity, malleability, ductility).
Dipole-dipole interactions, hydrogen bonding, and London dispersion forces. Effects on physical properties.
Detailed analysis of hydrogen bonding. Importance in biological systems (DNA, proteins).
Examples of how bonding theories are used to explain chemical reactivity and material properties.
